column4: I have a question. Is there a way I can see the outgoing ports that are open in Ubuntu?
you mean you want to scan your system and see what ports are open?
Yes, for outgoing connections, ie, which ports I can connect to on other machines.
iptraf is a good tool to look at network traffic/ports/etc...
iptraf, eh? That can scan ports that can potentially be used even if they're not in use?
it does a ton of stuff, I can't recall what though
you should hit the gibson research page and have it scan you
that will scan for incoming ports
https://www.grc.com/x/ne.dll?bh0bkyd2
what are you trying to accomplish?
if you want a box with a ton of ports open then just install XP
I want to see what outgoing ports are open on a certain machine as a security test.
you don't understand... ingoing/outgoing....
What do you call it, then, if I want to see if someone can use port 5198 to login to a remote AIM server?
someone on "what" running what OS, with what permissions, etc...
It's the firewall that is SUPPOSED to be blocking it. I want to VERIFY :-P
then try to telnet to that port on the AIM server
It's not that one port.
please read up on basic networking.
Thanks a lot. :-P
I'm not trying to blow you off, but you really don't seem to understand how things work and it would take all night to figure out what in the world you're doing.
What do you think I do not understand? Would my idea of pinging a range of ports on a machine with open ports not work?
pinging ports?
yes, say, nmap -p range mycomputerip
